items.synopsis: A 24-year-old woman faces court charged with the criminal neglect of two children in Whyalla on South Australia's Eyre Peninsula. Warning: This story contains details that some readers may find distressing.

title.children: Woman faces court charged with criminal neglect of children in Whyalla

items.synopsis: An Eyre Peninsula teacher charged with aggravated indecent assault has had his identity suppressed by the court.

title.children: South Australian teacher charged with aggravated indecent assault

items.synopsis: Senior public servant Kathryn Campbell resigns from the Department of Defence after coming under heavy criticism for her role in the Robodebt scandal.

title.children: Senior public servant in Robodebt scheme resigns from Department of Defence

image.altText: Stills of video which played a role in the Australian's four month investigation

items.synopsis: A senior lawyer and two First Nations executives have been appointed to review the APY Art Centre Collective (APYACC), following allegations of interference in Aboriginal art.

title.children: Panel appointed to review APY Art Centre Collective following allegations of interference

image.altText: A man in a wheelchair with his service dog standing with its paws on his lap

items.synopsis: A lack of legislation requiring local governments to provide public toilets means some areas are neglected, a researcher says.

title.children: Disability advocate calls for urgent action to address public bathroom shortage

image.altText: A sign for the Youth Court in Adelaide

items.synopsis: A 16-year-old girl has pleaded not guilty to the murder of a 55-year-old man, who was allegedly stabbed in Adelaide's north late last year.

title.children: Teenager charged with murder of Andrews Farm man pleads not guilty

image.altText: Brazilian and Panamanian fans smile at the camera as they hoild their national flags in the stands before a game.

items.synopsis: Germany gets off to a flying start with a big win over Morocco in Melbourne - next up is Brazil vs Panama after Italy takes the points earlier in the day against Argentina. Follow along in our live blog.

title.children: Germany crushes Morocco in Melbourne, Brazil - Panama to wrap up the day at the Women's World Cup

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: That was clearly coming. As I said, they have been mixing up their attack, and this time Debinha collected wide on the left and sent a perfect cross to Borges to nod it down and past the keeper. Bernadette Clarke in Adelaide: The Brazilian crowd has gone absolutely wild for their first goal of their World Cup campaign in Australia.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 19' GOOOAAL Brazil!

children.content: (Getty)
That was clearly coming.
As I said, they have been mixing up their attack, and this time Debinha collected wide on the left and sent a perfect cross to Borges to nod it down and past the keeper.
Bernadette Clarke
in Adelaide: The Brazilian crowd has gone absolutely wild for their first goal of their World Cup campaign in Australia.

props.alt: A canary mascot and fans celebrate

children.content: (Getty)

liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Brazil vs Panama is underway in Adelaide!

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: I think I counted right? Seriously though, not a great result in a World Cup where we've seen a narrowing of the gap betwen the heavyweights and the minnows. A huge statement from Germany, though, and strengthening the case of people like me who think they're the favourites here. Here's how Kate O'Halloran saw the game in Melbourne. It took just 23 seconds for the dam wall to break. For a half of football, Morocco held on gallantly. They may have trailed 0-2 at the break, but the underdogs had created a number of chances, and looked up for the fight. Within just half a minute of the restart, however, Klara Buehl made a dangerous run on the left hand side, delivering an excellent, floating cross to the back post. It was Buehl herself who ended up converting the shot from 7m out, breaking Moroccan hearts, as well as their resistance. By the 48th minute, the world number two ranked side looked to be toying with their opponents. Brand was able to walk a ball up to the box, before she passed to Magull, who nonchalantly left it for Buehl. The midfielder’s powerful strike missed, careering into the right-hand post, but it kickstarted a series of relentless efforts on goal for which the Atlas Lionesses appeared to have no answer. Two own goals followed, the latter at first looking like a Popp hattrick. Then, as full-time approached, the ruthless Germans scored again, this time through substitute Lea Schueller. In the end, the scoreline reflected the 70-place chasm between them; a contest between the world number 2 versus 72.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: FULL-TIME: Germany 6 - 0 Morocco

children.content: (Getty)
I think I counted right?
Seriously though, not a great result in a World Cup where we've seen a narrowing of the gap betwen the heavyweights and the minnows.
A huge statement from Germany, though, and strengthening the case of people like me who think they're the favourites here.
Here's how
Kate O'Halloran
saw the game in Melbourne.
It took just 23 seconds for the dam wall to break.
For a half of football, Morocco held on gallantly. They may have trailed 0-2 at the break, but the underdogs had created a number of chances, and looked up for the fight.
Within just half a minute of the restart, however, Klara Buehl made a dangerous run on the left hand side, delivering an excellent, floating cross to the back post.
It was Buehl herself who ended up converting the shot from 7m out, breaking Moroccan hearts, as well as their resistance.

By the 48th minute, the world number two ranked side looked to be toying with their opponents. Brand was able to walk a ball up to the box, before she passed to Magull, who nonchalantly left it for Buehl.
The midfielder’s powerful strike missed, careering into the right-hand post, but it kickstarted a series of relentless efforts on goal for which the Atlas Lionesses appeared to have no answer.
Two own goals followed, the latter at first looking like a Popp hattrick.
Then, as full-time approached, the ruthless Germans scored again, this time through substitute Lea Schueller.
In the end, the scoreline reflected the 70-place chasm between them; a contest between the world number 2 versus 72.

image.altText: Sam Kerr with a bandage on her left calf at a Matildas training session in Brisbane.

items.synopsis: The extent of Sam Kerr's injury remains a mystery after Matildas youngster Kyra Cooney-Cross caused a brief panic by mistakenly saying her teammate had torn her calf.

image.altText: Gladys Berejiklian looking serious.

items.synopsis: ICAC inspector Gail Furness SC has written to former treasurer Matt Kean to advise him of the investigation after he wrote a letter complaining about the former premier's treatment last month, the ABC understands.

title.children: ICAC chief to probe delay in Gladys Berejiklian report, possible maladministration

image.altText: Hundreds of hours of underwater vision reveals new understanding of Adelaide's Port River

items.synopsis: A researcher monitoring oysters and razorfish in Adelaide's Port River has noted the return of a resident not seen in the area for 10,000 years.

title.children: Ancient species surprises researchers as marine life fills major shipping port

image.altText: Wicks is standing in her place, holding a piece of paper and looking towards the Speaker (not in shot).

image.altText: A crashed car against a barrier with police attending.

image.altText: smiling older man looking at camera

image.altText: Blue and white police tape at a crime scene.

image.altText: An illustration of a woman crouched on a hospital bed with her head in her arms

image.altText: Iceberg in the Southern Ocean, seen from a ship.
